Make sure you use a lower-case -d, or else git won't warn you if your feature

comments.body: It prompts for deletion **because** git remembers history? I don't follow.

I just did this the other day.  I'm definitely sure I didn't do it the right way but when you make a section it basically says do you want to remove all the other .rsts.  If you say yes, it will delete them from your system so it doesn't find them to build (perhaps there is a better way to handle this through the build system).  What this is saying is that you can just checkout the old versions from the repository.
all I meant is that the phrasing is kinda awkward.

It is indeed correct, I only think the phrasing can be interpreted a bit wrongly -> it is _not a problem to delete_ the files because git will remember them (you just should not commit the deletions, only the changes).

The problem is that if the files are not deleted, you get a warnings about files that are not referenced. This is not really a problem, but that way the real warnings about the thing you are writing are less visible I think. But maybe there is a way to tell sphinx to ignore them.

comments.body: Are you sure this is necessary? I think Travis runs PRs anyway these days but I could be wrong.
I thought that was the case, but couldn't remember (when I set mine up, I had to do it manually).  If we can confirm it's automatic, we can adjust accordingly.
I think @kay1793 is correct. In the past it was manual.
I never set up travis for my pandas fork and always (aka in the last year or so) got travis output for all my PRs

It is indeed not needed anymore. But, if you want to get feedback from travis on a certain branch you push before you make it into a PR, then it can be useful. So maybe just a bit rephrasing that it is optional.
